content.raw:
Thanks.

To help me understand this PR, is the basic concept of a *Frame* here an extended Pose3 class, one with a reference to parent frame? Or is a Frame analogous to a physics::Link object, but without inertia, visual and collision children? 

As referenced in your gazebo_design PR, some users in the past have suggested adding a parent frame reference to each Pose3 object in gazebo math. I think that might actually be something we can consider, adding a parent frame object to Pose3.  If it's specified, a specific reference frame will be enforced. Otherwise, it will revert to the original intended parent frame where the Pose3 is used (and sometimes, one simply wants to specify a relative transform without specifying parent frame). This way we can make such an extension to Pose3 backwards compatible.

Alternatively, the physical frame object defines the pose of a basis relative to some [parent] frame.

Reading code, it'll take me a bit longer to understand which effect this PR is going for...

Thanks for clarification.
content.html:
Thanks.

To help me understand this PR, is the basic concept of a Frame here an extended Pose3 class, one with a reference to parent frame? Or is a Frame analogous to a physics::Link object, but without inertia, visual and collision children?

As referenced in your gazebo_design PR, some users in the past have suggested adding a parent frame reference to each Pose3 object in gazebo math. I think that might actually be something we can consider, adding a parent frame object to Pose3. If it's specified, a specific reference frame will be enforced. Otherwise, it will revert to the original intended parent frame where the Pose3 is used (and sometimes, one simply wants to specify a relative transform without specifying parent frame). This way we can make such an extension to Pose3 backwards compatible.

Alternatively, the physical frame object defines the pose of a basis relative to some [parent] frame.

Reading code, it'll take me a bit longer to understand which effect this PR is going for...

Thanks for clarification.

content.raw:
The idea is that in SDFormat, we can one day define "reference geometry", extended poses that refer to other named poses.
But the FrameGraph  that supports the feature does look like a collection of mass less links, or a hierarchical scene graph.
content.html: The idea is that in SDFormat, we can one day define "reference geometry", extended poses that refer to other named poses. But the FrameGraph that supports the feature does look like a collection of mass less links, or a hierarchical scene graph.

content.raw:
the two concepts are probably very nearly the same implementation wise, or could be identical. But I like staying grounded with potential target applications, it help me think about these things.

If we are going for `reference geometry` concept, it might be more succinct to extend Pose3 class, add a new member variable `parentFrame` and add various helper functions, etc.

If we are going for the mass-less link functionality, the use cases I can think of are to help describe a sensor or tool frame, followed by actual simulation of mass-less links, articulated kinematic robot models. This PR is a good starting point for it.
content.html:
the two concepts are probably very nearly the same implementation wise, or could be identical. But I like staying grounded with potential target applications, it help me think about these things.

If we are going for reference geometry concept, it might be more succinct to extend Pose3 class, add a new member variable parentFrame and add various helper functions, etc.

If we are going for the mass-less link functionality, the use cases I can think of are to help describe a sensor or tool frame, followed by actual simulation of mass-less links, articulated kinematic robot models. This PR is a good starting point for it.

content.raw:
Is this class used to describe path between two transforms? How does it work?

Being string based, there might be some severe performance issues if any sort of path computation / manipulation is needed.
content.html:
Is this class used to describe path between two transforms? How does it work?

Being string based, there might be some severe performance issues if any sort of path computation / manipulation is needed.

content.raw:
Yes,
The path are string based. In order to avoid path processing at runtime, there's a RelativePose class that retains the list of transforms to apply. Computing the pose is then a matter of going through the list, and applying poses.
content.html: Yes, The path are string based. In order to avoid path processing at runtime, there's a RelativePose class that retains the list of transforms to apply. Computing the pose is then a matter of going through the list, and applying poses.

content.raw: I mention performance issue because I recall `rospack find` and maybe libtf (@tfoote) had slow search performance when they were doing string based searches.
content.html: I mention performance issue because I recall rospack find and maybe libtf (@tfoote) had slow search performance when they were doing string based searches.

content.raw: Yes, iterating a list using string comparisons is very slow. The frame ids are strings, however internally all strings are immediately aliased to an integer. And all internal logic uses the integers for comparisons. Only out output is it turned back into a string. Which means for any operation the inputs are converted from string to int on input and for each output the reverse lookup is performed. We store them in a map. When a new string is encountered it's inserted into the forward and reverse lookup map with a unique int. It's never exposed so the user doesn't know about it, and it does not need to be coordinated between instances. The mappings will be different depending on which frameids were used first.
content.html: Yes, iterating a list using string comparisons is very slow. The frame ids are strings, however internally all strings are immediately aliased to an integer. And all internal logic uses the integers for comparisons. Only out output is it turned back into a string. Which means for any operation the inputs are converted from string to int on input and for each output the reverse lookup is performed. We store them in a map. When a new string is encountered it's inserted into the forward and reverse lookup map with a unique int. It's never exposed so the user doesn't know about it, and it does not need to be coordinated between instances. The mappings will be different depending on which frameids were used first.

content.raw:
I can see the benefits of this aliasing mechanism, especially in the case where a large number of lookup are performed.
The code in this PR assumes infrequent lookups (to create RelativePose objects), and transformation calculations without any lookup (using the RelativePose and the precomputed vector of frames to traverse). This model, along with the tree structure, seemed well suited for the SDF and Gazebo upgrade.

Having said that, what Tully describes can also be used here too. Is there a particular use case that should be considered?
content.html:
I can see the benefits of this aliasing mechanism, especially in the case where a large number of lookup are performed. The code in this PR assumes infrequent lookups (to create RelativePose objects), and transformation calculations without any lookup (using the RelativePose and the precomputed vector of frames to traverse). This model, along with the tree structure, seemed well suited for the SDF and Gazebo upgrade.

Having said that, what Tully describes can also be used here too. Is there a particular use case that should be considered?

content.raw:
The most basic description of a Frame is a parent frame name(id) and a pose.  Given Frames are used in graphs, a list of children frames is not part of the fundamental description of a Frame - i.e. one can compute the children on the fly given each frame and its parent. In fact, if you are supporting graph, you might want to keep a list of parents, a single parent implies a tree structure.

Maybe we should consider making `children` private and have some supporting member functions such as `Frame::AddChild`, `Frame::Children()`, etc.
content.html:
The most basic description of a Frame is a parent frame name(id) and a pose. Given Frames are used in graphs, a list of children frames is not part of the fundamental description of a Frame - i.e. one can compute the children on the fly given each frame and its parent. In fact, if you are supporting graph, you might want to keep a list of parents, a single parent implies a tree structure.

Maybe we should consider making children private and have some supporting member functions such as Frame::AddChild, Frame::Children(), etc.

content.raw:
I don't think you should be concerned about the public map, this is a PIMPL private class.
However you touched an important point with the tree structure, and something I struggled with during the design. The tree is simple, since any 2 frames can be reached by simply going up the hierarchy, and could accommodate the SDF requirements. Lets talk about Can we talk about this?.
content.html: I don't think you should be concerned about the public map, this is a PIMPL private class. However you touched an important point with the tree structure, and something I struggled with during the design. The tree is simple, since any 2 frames can be reached by simply going up the hierarchy, and could accommodate the SDF requirements. Lets talk about Can we talk about this?.

content.raw:
Doh! forgot this is private, yeah, perfectly good to keep `children` here.

In which case, [Frame constructor](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/pull-requests/66/frame_graph/diff#Linclude/ignition/math/Frame.hhT56) is totally precise.

On tree vs. graph issue, yeah, you might want to keep a list of children as well as a list of parents. And to be more precise, this is setup as a directed graph (since Pose3's are non-commutative). But it can be converted to an undirected graph once the graph is setup.
content.html:
Doh! forgot this is private, yeah, perfectly good to keep children here.

In which case, Frame constructor is totally precise.

On tree vs. graph issue, yeah, you might want to keep a list of children as well as a list of parents. And to be more precise, this is setup as a directed graph (since Pose3's are non-commutative). But it can be converted to an undirected graph once the graph is setup.

content.raw:
looking at FrameGraph API:

`FrameGraph::Pose(const std::string &_dst, const std::string &_src) const`

`FrameGraph::CreateRelativePose(const std::string &_srcPath, const std::string &_dstPath) const;`

One goes from `dst` to `src` while the other is `srcPath` to `dstPath`. Should the source and destination order be consistent?
content.html:
looking at FrameGraph API:

FrameGraph::Pose(const std::string &_dst, const std::string &_src) const

FrameGraph::CreateRelativePose(const std::string &_srcPath, const std::string &_dstPath) const;

One goes from dst to src while the other is srcPath to dstPath. Should the source and destination order be consistent?

content.raw:
RelativePose constructor is from src to dst:

`RelativePose::RelativePose(const FrameWeakPtr &_srcFrame, const FrameWeakPtr &_dstFrame)`
content.html:
RelativePose constructor is from src to dst:

RelativePose::RelativePose(const FrameWeakPtr &_srcFrame, const FrameWeakPtr &_dstFrame)

content.raw: Yes, everything should be consistent. Any preference?
content.html: Yes, everything should be consistent. Any preference?

content.raw:
This is because I was not sure deep copy of frame graphs should be in this PR, and I didn't want anyone to assume they were implemented (and find that multiple frameGraph instances share the same dataPtr).
I am happy to add a proper implementation if you see a case for it.
content.html: This is because I was not sure deep copy of frame graphs should be in this PR, and I didn't want anyone to assume they were implemented (and find that multiple frameGraph instances share the same dataPtr). I am happy to add a proper implementation if you see a case for it.
